speaker: Chorus
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: I come no more to make you laugh: things now,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That bear a weighty and a serious brow,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Sad, high, and working, full of state and woe,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Such noble scenes as draw the eye to flow,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: We now present. Those that can pity, here

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: May, if they think it well, let fall a tear;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The subject will deserve it. Such as give

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Their money out of hope they may believe,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: May here find truth too. Those that come to see

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Only a show or two, and so agree

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The play may pass, if they be still and willing,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: I'll undertake may see away their shilling

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Richly in two short hours. Only they

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That come to hear a merry bawdy play,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A noise of targets, or to see a fellow

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: In a long motley coat guarded with yellow,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Will be deceived; for, gentle hearers, know,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To rank our chosen truth with such a show

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: As fool and fight is, beside forfeiting

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Our own brains, and the opinion that we bring,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To make that only true we now intend,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Will leave us never an understanding friend.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Therefore, for goodness' sake, and as you are known

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The first and happiest hearers of the town,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Be sad, as we would make ye: think ye see

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: The very persons of our noble story

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: As they were living; think you see them great,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And follow'd with the general throng and sweat

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Of thousand friends; then in a moment, see

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: How soon this mightiness meets misery:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And, if you can be merry then, I'll say

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: A man may weep upon his wedding-day.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. London. An ante-chamber in the palace.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Enter NORFOLK at one door; at the other, BUCKINGHAM and ABERGAVENNY
